ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: review of latin grammar, historical context,  insight to translation
This course consolidated my Latin comprehension skills that I built in the summer. Professor Johnston also enriched our historical knowledge by often introducing relevant Roman historical context.
A solid grounding in Latin prose and ability to apply the grammatical structures that I leaned in Latin 110 and 120.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Very interesting topic and texts covered. Manageable workload and fair grading! I really liked how small the class was too! I've taken Latin for 7 years and this was by far the BEST class I have ever taken. The class was very well structured and thought out

Despite the online format of the course, Professor Johnston made sure that we had ample class interactions in the process of our translation. I am particularly happy that the Professor allowed us to, in one assignment, creatively translate Pro Caelio, which I think really helps me grasp the power dynamics of the Roman society.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I thought that although it would have been lovely and so beneficial to meet and connect with the other students in the class esp. since everyone was on such different paths but luckily the work was easy to do alone and translated well to just discussion.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: YES! I really enjoyed it and thought it was a great intro/continuation of latin.
I would definitely recommend this course to other students, especially with Professor Johnston, and to those who have taken Latin L1/2 in summer sessions.

Absolutely - you're probably taking it since it's required, but it's still an excellent class. I genuinely looked forward to the discussions and readings; Cicero and Professor Johnston? Can't go wrong!
